'COROT' (French: 'CO'nvection 'RO'tation et 'T'ransits planÃ©taires; English:
COnvection ROtation and planetary Transits) is a space mission led by the French
Space Agency (CNES) in conjunction with the European Space Agency (ESA) and
other international partners. The mission's two objectives are to search for
extrasolar planets with short orbital periods, particularly those of large
terrestrial size, and to perform asteroseismology by measuring solar-like
oscillations in stars. It was launched at 14:28:00 UTC
on 27 December 2006, atop a Soyuz 2.1b carrier rocket, reporting first
light on 18 January 2007. Subsequently, the
probe started to collect science data on 2 February 2007. http://www.cnes.fr/web/CNES-en/5749-corot-all-set-to-begin-science-
mission.php COROT is the first spacecraft dedicated to the detection of
transiting extrasolar planets, opening the way for more advanced probes such as
Kepler and possibly TESS and PLATO. It detected its first extrasolar planet, COROT-
1b, in May 2007, just 3 months after the start of
the observations. Mission flight operations were originally scheduled to end 2.5
years from launch but operations were extended to
2013. A new extension has been proposed to keep
COROT in operation till
2015. http://smsc.cnes.fr/COROT/PDF/CoRoT_III_programme.pdf On 2
November 2012, CoRoT suffered a computer failure that makes it impossible to
retrieve any data from its telescope; efforts for recovery are currently under
way. http://www.nature.com/news/exoplanet-hunter-nears-its-end-1.11845
On 24 June 2013, it was announced that CoRoT has been retired and would be
decommissioned, lowered in orbit to allow it to burn up in the atmosphere. SpaceDaily, [http://www.spacedaily.com/reports/Retirement_for_planet-
hunting_space_probe_999.html "Retirement for planet-hunting space probe"], AFP,
24 June 2013
categories: Extrasolar planets discovered by the COROT program|
